title: Another Kind of Substance Abuse

content: When you hear people talk about substance abuse, most of us think of drugs and alcohol. Most people don’t even think of food as being a substance that we can abuse. But our feelings can cause us to lose control of our food choices until they become just that. Emotional eating is a way to calm or suppress these negative feelings, such as anger, stress, fear, sadness, loneliness, and boredom.

It’s different for everyone, but major life changes, the struggles of daily life, and unresolved traumas may trigger you into emotional eating. When this happens, food choices may include foods that are not so healthy. This can lead to higher blood glucose levels, especially for people living with diabetes.

I’ve had my own struggles with emotional eating ever since I could remember. My food choices, eating frequency, and food portions were often determined by how I felt when it was time to eat. This happened with extreme emotions on both ends of the spectrum. If I was really sad, upset, or stressed, I would eat, and it would never be anything healthy. Also, if I was really happy and in a celebratory mood, I would celebrate with food, and this too was never with anything good for me.

content: I’ve mentioned before that I received my diabetes diagnosis at age 20. This doesn’t mean that my bad eating habits stopped at that point. I carried them with me and tried to manage the condition effectively with this bad eating behavior.

Over the years, a pattern developed: I’d be doing well with my diabetes management, and then out of nowhere, a bad, stressful day would happen. As this day went by, my eating choices got worse, and they came one after another. Then, the regret settled in after I checked my blood glucose level and it was higher than normal. At this point, my body was feeling fatigued, my mind became just as exhausted, and all I could say was, “I guess I’ll try again tomorrow.”

content: Imagine that you’re locked into this cycle. What about those times when your emotions last more than a day? One day of regret turns into a monthlong – or longer – binge. With your three-month checkup coming soon, you hate to have to explain to your doctor why your A1c has gone up this time. You just know for sure that your doctor is going to try to increase your dose of medications.

content: You don’t want that to happen because you don’t want to take the medication anyway. But you’re too ashamed to tell them what really happened, because the truth of the matter is that it makes you feel ashamed of yourself. You didn’t want to do it, but this was the only way for you to cope with your circumstances without anyone else knowing about it. This was my life over and over and over again for years.
I began to have a lot of complications, until in May 2019, I experienced the most life-changing diabetes complication of my life. I was completely blind for nine months.
At that point, every negative emotion that you could possibly think of came to live with me with the intention of staying there forever.
I guess your next question is, how did I get past it? I can’t tell you the trouble without telling you how I overcame it.

There was no theatrical “happening” or some dramatic scene that made me quit. I simply remember thinking that I was just tired of being depressed and allowing my emotions to take over my life. When I thought of my triumphant moments during my journey with diabetes, I immediately began to think of patterns that threw me off course every time. Each time that I allowed my emotions to get the best of me, I relied on food to be my pick-me-up.

Not only could my mind not take it anymore, but now my body couldn’t take it anymore either. It made me want to get rid of this horrible eating behavior because I still had dreams, aspirations, a purpose-driven life to live, and a beautiful son who was watching my every move.

content: It was an uphill battle with deciding not to buy unhealthy foods and not to eat too late in the evening, but most importantly what I should do when I have negative emotions. I begin to find other things to do, like calling a loved one. They probably didn’t know what I was doing then, but I guess they know now!

Also, I developed a habit of exercising when I felt stressed. Even if I couldn’t exercise at that moment, I became better at calming myself down until I could take it out on my body in a good way. The act of intentional breathing became my best friend as well. Deep breathing can help to relax your body to slow a rapid heart rate and rapid breathing in minutes.

Last but not least, it all boils down to the decision not to overeat, despite my cravings and what I felt my mind was telling me to do. This has taken years of practice. Sometimes, it still crosses my mind, but when I see how far I have come, I never want to go back to that dark place ever again.

content: Are your food choices dependent upon how you feel? For those of you who may be dealing with this eating behavior, you can break free from it. It started with you, so it should end with you. Never give up. Whatever you do, keep hope alive!
